title: R42741
content: The Federal Employees Health Benefits (FEHB) Program offers private health insurance to federal employees, retirees, and their dependents, providing over $40 billion in benefits annually. Approximately 8.2 million individuals are covered by FEHB each year, with 85% of federal employees and 90% of retirees participating. Coverage options include individual, family, and self plus one plans. Beginning in 2016, individuals will have a new coverage option in the Federal Employees Health Benefits (FEHB) Program: self plus one coverage for themselves and one eligible family member. FEHB offers fee-for-service (FFS) and health maintenance organizations (HMOs) plans with shared premiums between the federal government and the employee or retiree. All plans must cover basic services like hospital and physician care with varying cost sharing. Prior to the creation of FEHB in 1959, federal employees could not obtain health insurance through the government. They had to purchase coverage on their own or through union plans. Employers in the private sector started offering health insurance in the 1950s. President Truman's Commission recommended federal health insurance in 1951. The Federal Employees Health Benefits Act of 1959 (FEHBA) was passed by Congress to provide health insurance coverage for federal employees. It established eligibility parameters, types of health plans, benefits, and the government's share of premiums. An Employees Health Benefits Fund was also created to cover program expenses. The Federal Employees Health Benefits Act of 1959 (FEHBA) established an Employees Health Benefits Fund to pay for program expenses and outlined the role of the Office of Personnel Management (OPM). OPM has the authority to contract with insurers and manage FEHB. The general model of FEHB, with enrollees choosing coverage from private insurers, has remained unchanged despite amendments to the law. Employees and retirees share the cost of premiums with the federal government. The Federal Employees Health Benefits Act of 1959 (FEHBA) established the Employees Health Benefits Fund and the role of the Office of Personnel Management (OPM). While the general model of FEHB, with enrollees choosing coverage from private insurers, has not changed, aspects such as the government's share of premiums and eligibility have been modified over time by Congress. Policymakers play a role in proposing changes to the program. Since its inception, Congress has been involved in modifying the Federal Employees Health Benefits (FEHB) program. The FEHB model allows enrollees to choose coverage from competing insurers with minimal intervention from the Office of Personnel Management (OPM). This model is seen as successful in giving enrollees cost-conscious choices and controlling overall program costs. Researchers are interested in FEHB as a model for both private and public health insurance programs. Researchers have considered exporting aspects of the successful FEHB model to other health care programs, such as Medicare, or expanding access to FEHB for individuals outside of federal workers and retirees. Some policymakers have introduced legislation to create new programs or expand FEHB eligibility, with suggestions that FEHB features could serve as a model for state-level health programs. Congressional interest in FEHB goes beyond its potential as a model for other health care programs. Policymakers have a responsibility for FEHB's viability and sustainability, with suggestions that lessons learned from FEHB could inform the establishment of health insurance exchanges under the ACA. Congressional policymakers have a financial interest in the Federal Employees Health Benefits (FEHB) program, as the federal government has always contributed to its costs. Congress has the authority to restructure FEHB to maintain or improve its function. This report aims to explain the evolution of FEHB and how Congress has interacted with the program in the past. It also discusses certain changes to the program and how Congress has linked the use of federal funds to policy conditions. The report discusses how Congress has interacted with the Federal Employees Health Benefits (FEHB) program in the past, including conditioning the use of federal funds on policy changes, changing the formula for determining the government's share of FEHB premiums, modifying program eligibility, and implementing policies affecting the relationship between Medicare and FEHB. Congress has the authority to place conditions on federal funds to make changes to FEHB. In 1983, Congress passed a law prohibiting the use of federal funds for abortions under FEHB, except in cases of danger to the woman's life. This provision has been renewed annually with slight changes, except in 1994 and 1995 when it was excluded by the 103rd Congress. The provision was reinstated to allow funds for abortions in cases of danger to the woman's life, rape, or incest, and has been included in subsequent appropriations bills each year. Table 1 summarizes laws that have enacted policy changes to FEHB by placing conditions on the use of federal funds, with the government's share of premiums increasing over the years. The government's share was initially set at 50% of the premium and had to fall within a specified dollar range, but in 1971, the "big six" formula was created, equal to the simple average of the premiums of six health plans offered in FEHB meeting specified criteria. The "big six" formula was created in 1971, equal to the simple average of premiums of six health plans in FEHB. The government's share of premiums increased from 40% to 50% in 1974. In 1997, the Balanced Budget Act introduced the current formula where the government contributes 72% of the weighted average premium of all plans, not exceeding 75% of any one plan's premium. The government contributes 72% of the weighted average premium of all plans in the Federal Employees Health Benefits Act (FEHBA), not exceeding 75% of any one plan's premium. Eligibility for FEHB has been extended to more categories of federal employees, retirees, and their family members since its enactment. Since FEHBA's enactment, eligibility for FEHB has been extended to more categories of federal employees, retirees, and their family members. In 1978, part-time employees were included, and in 1988, certain temporary workers were also covered. Congress authorized temporary continuation of coverage (TCC) in 1988 for separating employees and their dependents for up to 18 months after separation, with TCC enrollees paying the entire FEHB premium plus a 2% administrative fee. Since its establishment, FEHB eligibility has expanded to include more federal employees, retirees, and their families. TCC allows separating employees and dependents to continue coverage for up to 18 months, with enrollees paying the full premium plus a 2% fee. Exceptions include 36 months of coverage for children aging out of their parents' plans. In 1982, Congress passed a law applying Medicare's Hospital Insurance tax to federal employment, changing the interaction between FEHB and Medicare. In 1982, Congress passed the Tax Equity and Fiscal Responsibility Act (P.L. 97-248), which extended Medicare eligibility to federal workers based on their employment. Additionally, the Federal Employees Health Benefits Act of 1959 (P.L. 86-382) established the FEHB program for federal employees, outlining eligibility and enrollment procedures. The FEHB program for federal employees was established by P.L. 86-382 on July 1, 1960. It outlined eligibility criteria for current employees and retirees, including enrollment procedures, benefit types, premium shares, and OPM's role. Retirees needed to have at least 12 years of service or retire due to disability after July 1, 1960, and be enrolled in an FEHB plan for five years prior to retirement. OPM could contract or approve different types of health benefit plans for participation in FEHB, including Service Benefit Plan and Indemnity Benefit Plan, as well as Employee Organization Plans. Retirees needed to have at least 12 years of service or retire due to disability, and be enrolled in an FEHB plan for five years prior to retirement. Family members of employees and retirees were also eligible for coverage. Comprehensive Medical Plans are either group-practice prepayment plans or individual-practice plans. Employee Organization Plans provide health benefits to members of the organization and are available only to employees, retirees, and their families who are members of the organization at the time of enrollment. Medical Plans can be group-practice prepayment plans or individual-practice prepayment plans. The government's share of premiums in FEHB plans under P.L. 86-382 depended on the type of plan and enrollee, with a 50% share for service benefit and indemnity plans. The government's share of premiums in FEHB plans under P.L. 86-382 depended on the type of plan and enrollee, with a 50% share for service benefit and indemnity plans. For employees and retirees with individual or family coverage, the biweekly government share had specific minimum and maximum amounts. The government's share of premiums in FEHB plans under P.L. 86-382 varied based on the type of plan and enrollee, with a 50% share for service benefit and indemnity plans. For employees and retirees with individual or family coverage, the government's share was 50% of the biweekly premium if it was less than $2.50 for individual coverage and less than $6.00 for family coverage. Female employees or retirees with family coverage received a 30% government share if the biweekly premium was less than $6.00. P.L. 86-568 authorized FEHB coverage for employees of county committees under the Soil Conservation and Domestic Allotment Act. P.L. 88-59 extended the deadline for applications to participate in FEHB from December 31, 1959, to December 31, 1963, and eliminated the requirement for offering health care benefits prior to applying. P.L. 88-284, passed on March 17, 1964, expanded FEHB coverage to include employees with work-related injuries, foster children, and unmarried children. It removed the requirement for employee organizations to offer health benefits before applying for FEHB. P.L. 88-284, enacted on March 17, 1964, expanded FEHB coverage to include employees with work-related injuries, foster children, and unmarried children up to age 21. It also allowed retirees to continue their FEHB coverage if enrolled by December 31, 1964. Additionally, it granted OPM discretionary authority to terminate contracts with carriers not meeting enrollment requirements and equalized the government's share of premiums for all enrollees. The government's share of premiums for employee organization plans and comprehensive medical plans was changed by the act. For enrollees in these plans with biweekly premiums less than twice the government share, the government's share was set at 50% for both individual and family plans. P.L. 88-531 authorized FEHB coverage for certain United States commissioners and their dependents if the Civil Service Retirement Act applies to the commissioners. It also allowed certain teachers employed by the Board of Education of the District of Columbia to participate in a health benefits plan established under the Federal Employees Health Benefits Act of 1959. It also provided retroactive salary increases for certain federal government employees and preserved benefits for Congressional staff receiving fellowships. Enrollment costs increased to $1.62 for individual and $3.94 for family plans, not exceeding 50% of the total premium. Dependent children coverage extended to age 22. Employees on leave without pay for full-time officer roles could maintain FEHB coverage. National Guard technicians became eligible for FEHB coverage starting January 1, 1969. The Federal Magistrates Act of 1968 and subsequent acts expanded FEHB coverage for federal employees, including those transferring to international organizations. P.L. 91-418 in 1970 adjusted the government's premium contribution. P.L. 91-418 in 1970 changed the government's share of health insurance premiums by introducing the "big six" formula, which calculates the average of premiums from six benefit plans to reflect medical price inflation. The government's share of health insurance premiums was changed by P.L. 91-418 in 1970 through the introduction of the "big six" formula. This formula calculates the average of premiums from six benefit plans to reflect medical price inflation. The act also allowed family members of deceased employees or retirees with less than five years of service to continue enrollment in an FEHB plan. P.L. 93-363, enacted on July 30, 1974, allowed FEHB enrollees direct access to licensed optometrists and clinical psychologists without the need for supervision or referral by another practitioner. The amendments in P.L. 94-310 granted FEHB enrollees direct access to optometrists and clinical psychologists without supervision or referral. This amendment aims to establish uniformity in Federal Employee Health benefits. It provided protections to medically underserved populations and ensured that if an FEHB contract covered a health service cost, it would be provided from January 1, 1980, to December 31, 1984. This act also made Medicare payments secondary for employees aged 65 to 69 covered under certain employer group health plans. The Consolidated Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1985 (P.L. 99-272) required OPM to determine minimum financial reserves for health plan carriers to ensure stability.
